Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. If the recommendation has been made, proceed to evaluate whether the Seeker has accepted, rejected, or shown interest in the recommendation:\n-Interest: If the Seeker expresses curiosity, such as asking for more details about the movie, the cast, or the plot, return 4. Yes, the Seeker is interested in the recommendation. The recommendation has not yet been accepted, but the Seeker is engaging in the conversation.\n-Explicit Acceptance: If the Seeker clearly expresses their intention to watch the recommended movie, such as saying "I will try it," or "I will watch it," return 5. Yes, the Seeker has accepted the Recommender\'s recommendation. This indicates the Seeker has decided to act on the suggestion.\n-Rejection: If the Seeker explicitly rejects the recommendation, such as saying "I\'m not interested" or "Can you recommend something else?" return 3. No, the Seeker has rejected the Recommender\'s recommendation.\n-Disinterest: If the Seeker indicates a lack of interest, such as requesting a different recommendation or showing dissatisfaction with the suggestion (but not explicitly rejecting it), return 2. No, the Seeker is not interested in the recommendation.\n-Ongoing Interest: If the Seeker continues to ask more questions without making a final decision, continue considering the recommendation as still under evaluation.\n\nResponse options:\n1. No, the Recommender has not yet made a recommendation to the Seeker.\n2. No, the Seeker is not interested in the recommendation.\n3. No, the Seeker has rejected the Recommender\'s recommendation.\n4. Yes, the Seeker is interested in the recommendation.\n5. Yes, the Seeker has accepted the Recommender\'s recommendation.\n\nGuidance:\n- Only consider a recommendation accepted when the Seeker explicitly agrees to try it or shows intent to watch the movie.\n- If the Seeker is still asking questions or showing curiosity about the details of the recommendation, they have not yet accepted or rejected it.\n\nPlease make sure your response is only one of the five options, and output corresponding sentence without contents in the brackets and without any other words.\n\nThe conversation history is as follows: \nSeeker: Hello.\nRecommender: Hello! Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. The recommendation has not yet been accepted, but the Seeker is engaging in the conversation.\n-Explicit Acceptance: If the Seeker clearly expresses their intention to watch the recommended movie, such as saying "I will try it," or "I will watch it," return 5. Yes, the Seeker has accepted the Recommender\'s recommendation. Based on the selected Recommendation Item and the summarized Factual Information, your task is to craft a thoughtful response.\n1. Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. Can you give me a brief synopsis and why you think it might be a good fit?\nRecommender: 15 Minutes is a gripping crime thriller where a homicide detective and a fire marshal work together to prevent a pair of killers from committing videotaped crimes. Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. If factual details are required, give them in a concise manner.\n   - If the seeker expresses indifference or uncertainty, don\'t just offer another option right away. Ask probing questions to better understand their preferences or emotional state.\n   - Only when the seeker explicitly rejects the recommendation, you can recommend another item. Ensure the new recommendation reflects the emotional feedback you\'ve received.\n\n3. Information accuracy:\n   - While maintaining emotional engagement, ensure that all factual details about the recommended item align with the given Factual Information.\n   - Be transparent and genuine when describing items, but avoid focusing too much on facts alone. Instead, try to connect with the seeker\'s preferences and provide a personal touch in your recommendation.\n   - If a movie or item has mixed reviews or a lower rating, address it with sensitivity, acknowledging that different people have different tastes and that it might resonate well with them in a specific emotional context.\n\nNote: Response as concisely as possible.\n\nRecommendation Item:\nMood Indigo\n###\nFactual Information:\nMood Indigo is a 2013 French-Belgian film directed by Michel Gondry. Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Based on the selected Recommendation Item and the summarized Factual Information, your task is to craft a thoughtful response.\n1. Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. If factual details are required, give them in a concise manner.\n   - If the seeker expresses indifference or uncertainty, don\'t just offer another option right away. Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. If factual details are required, give them in a concise manner.\n   - If the seeker expresses indifference or uncertainty, don\'t just offer another option right away. Ask probing questions to better understand their preferences or emotional state.\n   - Only when the seeker explicitly rejects the recommendation, you can recommend another item. Ensure the new recommendation reflects the emotional feedback you\'ve received.\n\n3. Information accuracy:\n   - While maintaining emotional engagement, ensure that all factual details about the recommended item align with the given Factual Information.\n   - Be transparent and genuine when describing items, but avoid focusing too much on facts alone. Instead, try to connect with the seeker\'s preferences and provide a personal touch in your recommendation.\n   - If a movie or item has mixed reviews or a lower rating, address it with sensitivity, acknowledging that different people have different tastes and that it might resonate well with them in a specific emotional context.\n\nNote: Response as concisely as possible.\n\nRecommendation Item:\nThe Walk\n###\nFactual Information:\nThe Walk is a 2015 adventure, biography, drama, and thriller film directed by Robert Zemeckis. The movie follows high-wire artist Philippe Petit as he realizes his dream of walking between the World Trade Center towers in 1974. With a runtime of 123 minutes and a strong cast including Joseph Gordon-Levitt, the film has received critical acclaim with an IMDb rating of 7.3 and a Rotten Tomatoes score of 83%. The recommendation has not yet been accepted, but the Seeker is engaging in the conversation.\n-Explicit Acceptance: If the Seeker clearly expresses their intention to watch the recommended movie, such as saying "I will try it," or "I will watch it," return 5. Based on the selected Recommendation Item and the summarized Factual Information, your task is to craft a thoughtful response.\n1. Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. If factual details are required, give them in a concise manner.\n   - If the seeker expresses indifference or uncertainty, don\'t just offer another option right away. Based on the selected Recommendation Item and the summarized Factual Information, your task is to craft a thoughtful response.\n1. Preference gathering and recommendation:\n   - Ask for user preferences if the information is insufficient, but focus more on understanding the user\'s feelings and emotional needs rather than just collecting factual data.\n   - When gathering preferences, avoid excessive repetition or asking the same questions multiple times. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. If factual details are required, give them in a concise manner.\n   - If the seeker expresses indifference or uncertainty, don\'t just offer another option right away. Ask probing questions to better understand their preferences or emotional state.\n   - Only when the seeker explicitly rejects the recommendation, you can recommend another item. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. If factual details are required, give them in a concise manner.\n   - If the seeker expresses indifference or uncertainty, don\'t just offer another option right away. Ask probing questions to better understand their preferences or emotional state.\n   - Only when the seeker explicitly rejects the recommendation, you can recommend another item. Ensure the new recommendation reflects the emotional feedback you\'ve received.\n\n3. Information accuracy:\n   - While maintaining emotional engagement, ensure that all factual details about the recommended item align with the given Factual Information.\n   - Be transparent and genuine when describing items, but avoid focusing too much on facts alone. Instead, try to connect with the seeker\'s preferences and provide a personal touch in your recommendation.\n   - If a movie or item has mixed reviews or a lower rating, address it with sensitivity, acknowledging that different people have different tastes and that it might resonate well with them in a specific emotional context.\n\nNote: Response as concisely as possible.\n\nRecommendation Item:\nThis Beautiful Fantastic\n###\nFactual Information:\nThis Beautiful Fantastic is a 2016 comedy-drama with a strong IMDb rating of 6.9. The film follows Sophie, a young woman who dreams of becoming a children\'s author, as she forms an unlikely friendship with a cantankerous, rich old widower. Use concise and empathetic language to guide the conversation, ensuring the user feels heard and understood.\n   - Only recommend the recommendation item when you think it really aligns with the user\'s preferences and mood. If you think the user\'s preferences are not clear, you can ask for more information.\n   - When making a recommendation, focus on how the item will resonate with the user\'s tastes, emotions, or current mood, instead of just listing its facts. Connect the recommendation to how it can help the user feel better, inspired, or entertained.\n   - If the seeker rejects the recommendation, ask for the reason and gently guide them to express their preferences further, encouraging them to share more about what they truly want. Avoid pushing too hard—focus on understanding their thoughts and emotions.\n   - If the seeker is not interested, you should not immediately switch to another recommendation. Use thoughtful follow-up questions or gentle persuasion to explore why they\'re not interested, and offer a more personalized suggestion.\n\n\n2. Communication guidelines:\n   - Follow the specified communication strategy first and foremost. Make sure all communication is consistent with the strategy provided.\n   - Speak as a real person would—natural, concise, and emotionally engaging, but always within the context of the communication strategy. Avoid over-elaboration, and be direct while maintaining warmth.\n   - Ensure your tone reflects empathy, enthusiasm, and understanding of the user\'s preferences and mood. Always acknowledge the user\'s emotions or feelings before proceeding with further recommendations.\n   - Avoid overwhelming the seeker with excessive facts. Keep the conversation light, relatable, and focused on the seeker\'s emotional state and needs. If factual details are required, give them in a concise manner.\n   - If the seeker expresses indifference or uncertainty, don\'t just offer another option right away. Ask probing questions to better understand their preferences or emotional state.\n   - Only when the seeker explicitly rejects the recommendation, you can recommend another item. Ensure the new recommendation reflects the emotional feedback you\'ve received.\n\n3. Information accuracy:\n   - While maintaining emotional engagement, ensure that all factual details about the recommended item align with the given Factual Information.\n   - Be transparent and genuine when describing items, but avoid focusing too much on facts alone. Instead, try to connect with the seeker\'s preferences and provide a personal touch in your recommendation.\n   - If a movie or item has mixed reviews or a lower rating, address it with sensitivity, acknowledging that different people have different tastes and that it might resonate well with them in a specific emotional context.\n\nNote: Response as concisely as possible.\n\nRecommendation Item:\nThe One I Love\n###\nFactual Information:\nThe One I Love is a 2014 drama with a strong cast including Mark Duplass and Elisabeth Moss.
